text:
BILLY CRUDUP: It's not a
pleasant experience typically,
watching myself work.

The best feeling
I typically have

is, oh, I didn't crap
myself on that one.

I mean that's really,
that's high praise for me.

I can remember when I was, I
want to say like fourth grade

or something, they
had these little books

where you kind of write what
you want to be when you grow up,
et cetera.

And I wanted to be Bruce Jenner
when I grew up, it was 1976,

and he had just won the
decathlon, or a lawyer.

But I didn't know
anybody who was an actor.

So I was dubious about
becoming an actor.

And so I went to graduate
school to get my master's
so that I could teach.

It was clear that I didn't,
I didn't want to teach.
I didn't want an academic--
I wanted to perform.

What I really needed was to be
around serious minded people,

who were considering this as
a, a serious occupation, not

something to try to do just, you
know, for [bleep] and giggles.

I kind of really enjoyed
playing [bleep] in "Jesus' Son."

Good luck using that,
but that is his name, OK.

It was an independent
movie and there
wasn't a lot of money involved.

And the woman who
was producing it

and wrote it and was
a big engine behind it

all, Elizabeth Cuthrell,
I said, all right,

you don't have to
give me anything

except for one of those cast
chairs that says [bleep]
on the back.
So I have that in my apartment.
When I kept it--

the back to the wall so
my son wouldn't see it.

Once he discovered it, thought
it was the greatest thing ever.

I would say, you're
going to come with me

and I'm going to talk to you,
for much longer than you want,

about what a difficult and
rigorous profession this is.

And you should make this
decision with great confidence
and only if you have to.

Because this is a profession
that, even if you're

successful, your life will
change in unpredictable ways
that are not easy to manage.

I'm always looking
for ways to improve
something that I've done.

I think one of the things that
you aspire to as an actor is

to be a part of a collaboration
that is after something unique,

something, some kind of
storytelling that is singular.

I'm not somebody who can
create my own material.

I have no idea how
to direct anything.

The best I can do is like,
jump on the bandwagon

of somebody who's kick ass,
and ride on their coattails.
